discussion.content: G.723 is NOT the same as G723.1 (available in CUCM). SO the answer for that question is correct. G.729 will allow for most number of calls.
G.723 (G.723.1) needs less BW (5.3/6.3 kbps) then G.729. It is not that well supported as G.729.

comments.content:
G.723 is completely different than G.723.1

G.723 is an ITU standard for speech codecs that uses the ADPCM method and provides good quality audio at 24 and 40 Kbps.

Note: G.723 codec mainly used for digital circuit multiplication equipment (DCME) applications. And latter folded into G.726. Kindly see the G.726

G.723.1 is a speech codec that compresses voice audio in 30 ms frames. An algorithmic look-ahead of 7.5 ms duration means that total algorithmic delay is 37.5 ms.

questions.question_text: When a remote office location is set up with limited bandwidth resources, which codec would allow the most voice calls with the limited bandwidth?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. This INVITE is sent to an endpoint that only supports G.729. What must be done for this call to succeed?

discussion.content: Answer is B. "A transcoder takes the media stream of one codec and transcodes (converts) it from one compression type to another compression type. For example, it could take a stream from a G.711 codec and transcode (convert) it in real time to a G.729 stream. In addition to codec conversion, a transcoder resource can also provide MTP/TRP functionality to a call."

Answer B
D. Nothing: both sides support payload type 101: Payload type 101 refers to DTMF events, not the actual audio codec

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
101 is "telephone-event" --> DTMF

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer is B.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/voice/cube/configuration/cube-book/dtmf-relay.html

i think the reason it allows SUBSCRIBE/NOTIFY is because it allows kpml. subscribe is just the initial registration of the NOTIFY out-of-band method. the actual keys are transmitted in the NOTIFY then:
sip-kpml â€”This method is available only on SIP dial peers. The RFC 4730 defines the out-of-band DTMF relay mechanism to register the DTMF signals using the SIP-Subscribe messages. It transports the DTMF signals using the SIP-Notify messages containing an XML-encoded body. This method is calked Key Press Markup Language.

If you configure KPML on the dial peer, the gateway sends INVITE messages with KPML in the Allow-Events header.

NOTIFY sip:192.168.105.25:5060 SIP/2.0
Event: kpml 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

choices.B: Add a transcoder that supports G.711ulaw and G.729.
choices.D: Nothing: both sides support payload type 101.
choices.C: Add a media termination point that supports G.711ulaw and G.729.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Endpoint A calls endpoint B. What is the only audio codec that can be used for the call?

discussion.content: The DTMF Events through SIP Signaling feature allows telephone event notifications to be sent through SIP NOTIFY messages, using the SIP SUBSCRIBE/NOTIFY method as defined in the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) draft, SIP-Specific Event Notification.

Selected Answer: DE
D,E correct answer.

comments.content: After more study I believe they are looking for SUBSCRIBE & NOTIFY. Seems to be a Cisco thing. I haven't seen it in the general world of SIP.

discussion.content: I think it should be B & C (PRACK & UPDATE). Both of these include SDP where DTMF is negotiated.

SUBSCRIBE - subscribes for an event of notification from the notifier ( KPML & MWI)
NOTIFY - Notify the subscriber of a new event ( used for KPML $ MWI)
I'm going to have to investigate this question. I don't see any DTMF negotiation in this message. Nothing like telephony-event 101 configuration.
Thank you so much for the explanation :)
